This includes supervisory, disciplinary and civil regulatory action (but not criminal action) the FCA and/or PRA has taken, has decided or proposed to take and considers appropriate to publish.It also includes civil penalties the FCA has imposed or decided to impose. It does not include action taken by other enforcement agencies . Date Type of Action Enforcement Type 19/12/2013 Fines The Financial Services Authority ("FSA") imposed a financial penalty of £10.5 million on Card Protection Plan Ltd ("CPP"). The FSA's action took effect on 14 November 2012 and a copy of the Final Notice, which sets out the reason for the action, is displayed on the FSA's web site and can be accessed using the following link:http://www.fsa.gov.uk/static/pubs/final/card-protection-plan.pdfThe reason for this action was that CPP failed to comply with Principles 3, 6 and 7 of the FSA's Principles for Businesses. full_panel.header: Appointed representatives / tied agents / PSD or EMD agents
full_panel.body: An appointed representative is a firm or individual that can act on behalf of another firm or individual (its 'principal') that is authorised by the PRA and/or FCA. A tied agent can act on behalf of another firm or individual (its 'principal') that is regulated in another country in the European Economic Area (EEA). Appointed representatives and tied agents promote or deal in the products of their principal rather than all products in the market.A PSD or EMD agent is a firm that can act on behalf of another firm (its 'principal') that is authorised or registered by the FCA as a payment or e-money institution.The principal is responsible for the activities of its agents. Previously attached to: ‘Agent status’ shows whether an agent currently has an active relationship with any principal firm. An authorised firm will have permission to provide certain regulated products and services. Client Money This firm cannot hold client money. It may be able to control client money if it has the necessary requirements. RequirementsRequirements are rules placed on the firm that apply to all of the financial services activities that it can operate. Conduct a past business review CPP must carry out a past business review overseen by a skilled person appointed under section 166 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 to ascertain the customers which may have suffered detriment (and the extent of any loss) as a result of sales and/or renewals conducted by CPP of its Card Protection policies since 14 January 2005 and sales of Identity Protection through CPP's telephone sales channels since 14 January 2005 (but, in both cases, only where the original sale did not involve one of CPP's business partners making an introduction or conducting the sale); Cease material asset movements unless FSA approved The variation of permission requested the addition of a requirement in its permission that CPP:(a) Will not, without the FSA's prior written agreement, carry out any of the following: (i) material movements of assets to its parent or any other companies within its group; (ii) material changes to its capital structure or remuneration policy; (iii) the payment of any proposed dividend; and (iv) any other significant alteration in the composition or quality of CPP's assets; and(b) Will promptly disclose to the FSA all transfers and/or payments which do not relate to normal trading activities Must not use assets as security With effect from 1 April 2013 the firm Card Protection Plan Ltd (CPPL) must not, without the FSA prior written agreement, permit the use of the firm's assets as security for borrowing by any other company. Must not enter into agreement The firm must not, without the FSA's prior written agreement, enter into any agreement with a connected person for the provision of goods, services, loans or credit, unless the terms are equivalent to terms had the arrangements been entered into with an unconnected third party and in particular the terms must be representative of market value. Must not carry out automatic renewal The firm must not carry out an automatic renewal of existing insurance contracts previouslyrenewed by using the authopaycard process without the customer expressly confirming the paymentmethod to be used for renewal. The firm must not seek to retain a customer whose The firm must not seek to retain a customer whose contract it requesting to cancel their insurance contract. Firm must undertake a consumer redress exercise The firm is required to establish and operate a consumer redress scheme in respect of those customers who were mis-sold policies.' Policies' or ('policy') means the firm's Card Protection Product, where the sale (or renewal) was on or after 14 January 2005 and was before the relevant Amendment Date (as defined in the scheme documentation); and/or the firm's Identity Protection Product, where the sale (or renewal) was on or after 14 January 2005 and the sale was by telephone. The amount of redress may be calculated to off-set any claims made under the policy. This customer redress scheme must be implemented no later than 30 April 2014. Such consumer redress scheme shall be binding on the Financial Ombudsman Service. Further details are available on the FCA website: www.fca.org.uk Must cease all regulated activities except for The firm must cease all regulated activities except for the following activities:(i) Arranging and renewing insurance contracts where:(a) the insurance contract is part of a packaged bank account; (a) packaged bank accountbeing an arrangement under which a firm provides a retail banking service as part of apackage which includes access to other goods and services, whether or not a fee is charged) or(b) the insurance contract is part of a credit card account (a credit card account being anarrangement where a licensee, firm, payment service provider or electronic money insurerenter into a regulated consumer credit agreement with a customer as part of a packagewhich may include access to other goods and services, whether or not a fee is charged); or(c) the insurance contract is an ancillary insurance contract (an ancillary insurance contract being an insurance contract, which is included at the point of inception as part of an insurance package provided by another firm to a customer and which is not sold to the customer as an additional benefit of the home or motor insurance package for which the customer must pay an incremental premium). (ii) renewals of insurance contracts to customers who have a contract in force on 15 November 2012; (iii) administration and performance, including claims handling, of insurance contracts; and (iv) provision of credit information services. Amendment to a consumer redress exercise The Requirements became effective on 13 August 2013. The Requirements shall be supplemented as follows: The definition of 'Scheme of Arrangement' at paragraph 1.28 of the Requirements shall mean the solvent scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006 as sanctioned by the Court on 14 January 2014 (as subsequently modified in accordance with its terms) and as described more particularly in Annex 1 to this Supplemental Requirement. Changes to the Scheme of Arrangement as appended to Part 1 of Annex C to the Requirements are highlighted through underlined or struck through text. All references in the Requirements to "Scheme Document" shall be references to the Scheme of Arrangement described more particularly in Annex 1 hereto. Paragraph 5.1 of Part 3 of Annex C of the Requirements shall be amended so as to read as follows: "If a Scheme Creditor disagrees with the amount of compensation payable to him, he may initiate the Dispute Resolution Procedure to refer the dispute to the Scheme Adjudicator, provided he does so within the time limits specified in Clauses 4.5 and 4.8 of the Scheme Document. If a Scheme Creditor disagrees with the rejection of his Claim Form by the Scheme Administrators, and provided that the Claim Form was received on or before 22 July 2016, he may initiate the Dispute Resolution Procedure to refer the dispute to the Scheme Adjudicator, provided he does so within the time limits specified in Clauses 4.7 to 4.9 of the Scheme Document.
